text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Minister of aviation to make fresh pronouncement on domestic air fares following stay of action by airline operators on their proposal to raise the fares by 200 percent.
- WEMA Bank drops plans to buy the distressed National Bank of Nigeria following new requirement that banks increase their capital base nine fold, banking sources say.
- Police quiz six persons including a senior lawyer over murder of a Catholic priest in midwestern Nigeria.
- Nigeria's first lady Maryam Abacha starts French language lessons.
- Kaduna Textiles Limited, one of the nation's biggest textile mills, acquires machinery worth 175 million naira for first phase of its modernisation plan.
- Federal government says United Nations team due in Nigeria on Sunday will not meet political detainees as is being widely speculated.
- Registration of voters for elections in the military government's transition to civil rule plan ends on Wednesday.
- Rivers state government offers 1.35 billion naira life-line to oil palm company Risonpalm Limited to enable it complete three projects formerly funded by European Union.
- Italy says the pull out of its utility firm Enel from the $4 billion Nigeria liquefied natural gas project is not for political reasons.
- Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group meeting in London calls for new memoranda on Nigeria.
- Mobil oil company introduces upgraded lubricants into the Nigerian market.
- Tyre maker Dunlop unveils new marketing strategies at its national sales conference in Ota, Ogun state.
- Shareholders of International Merchant Bank approve bid to recapitalise the bank.
